#Text=Price Tattoos
#Text=The only way to get a reliable quote for a tattoo is to set up a consultation with your tattoo artist .
#Text=This is because prices can vary by hundreds of dollars depending on your shop and specific tattoo .
#Text=If you ca n't wait until your consultation , though , there are a few ways you can get a rough estimate for your tattoo .
#Text=You can try emailing your artist or estimating based on their hourly rate .
#Text=You can also check reviews for your shop to see how much others have paid for tattoos there .
#Text=Just remember that the cost of your tattoo will depend on a number of factors including size , color , and level of detail .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Talking to Your Artist
#Text=Schedule a consultation with your intended artist .
#Text=To get an accurate estimate for your tattoo , the best thing you can do is schedule a consultation to talk specifically about what you want .
#Text=Generally , artists will require you to make an appointment in advance for a consultation , so call your intended shop or artist so that you can talk about the tattoo you plan to get .
#Text=Have an idea for both your tattoo design and placement .
#Text=When you go to your consultation , you should have a rough idea of not only the design but also about how big you want your tattoo to be and where you want it placed on your body .
#Text=Be prepared to talk about things like color palette and shading , too .
#Text=It can help to bring along pictures or drawings that you are using for inspiration so that your artist can get a better idea of exactly what you want .
#Text=Send an email inquiry .
#Text=Many shops ' websites have forms you can use to make initial inquiries .
#Text=Include as complete a description of your tattoo as you can when you fill out the form .
#Text=If they allow image uploads , include any drawings or photos that you have been using for inspiration .
#Text=Email estimates will typically not be as accurate as those from consultations , but they can give you a general range of potential prices .
#Text=Ask your artist about their hourly rate if you are planning on a big piece .
#Text=Larger pieces are often priced by the hour instead of by the piece .
#Text=If you plan on getting a larger tattoo , such as a sleeve or full back piece , ask your artist about their hourly rate .
#Text=Give them an idea of the piece you want so they can give you an estimate of how long it will take .
#Text=Evaluating Price by Shop
#Text=Inquire about the shop minimum if you are getting a small piece .
#Text=If you are getting a small tattoo such as a single word in a basic font or a small symbol with no shading , you may be subject to a shop minimum .
#Text=Your artist or the shop manager should be able to tell you the minimum .
#Text=Consider the popularity of the shop .
#Text=Getting your tattoo done at a popular shop could increase the price you pay for your piece .
#Text=If your shop has a world-famous artist working at it , expect to pay more .
#Text=Likewise , if your shop is locally popular and consistently booked due to its reputation for high-quality tattoos , you can expect your tattoo to be more expensive .
#Text=Check online reviews for the shop .
#Text=Sites like Yelp are great places to check to get an idea of how much a tattoo could cost .
#Text=Check online reviews for your shop to see how much people have paid in the past for pieces of similar size and with similar styles and levels of detail .
#Text=Estimating Cost
#Text=Look at your artist 's past works to get an idea of their skill .
#Text=More talented and experienced artists will generally have higher prices .
#Text=Take a look at your artist 's portfolio and work history to get an idea of their skill level .
#Text=If they are known for their elaborate or detailed tattoos , do n't be surprised if they have an hourly rate of over $ 120 - 150 USD .
#Text=Consider the size of your tattoo .
#Text=The larger your tattoo will be , the more you will pay for it .

#Text=A small tattoo without much detail will often cost no more than the shop minimum , while larger tattoos about the size of a deck of playing cards could easily run anywhere between $ 100 and $ 200 USD .
#Text=Placement will also impact the cost of your tattoo .
#Text=The more sensitive the area or the more difficult it is to tattoo , the more the piece will cost .
#Text=An inner lip , tattoo , for example , may cost more than other small tattoos .
#Text=Factor in the amount of detail you want in your tattoo .
#Text=Size , alone , is not going to determine the cost of your work .
#Text=The amount of detail in your tattoo will also factor into the cost .
#Text=The more fine details , vivid colors , and shading you have , the more expensive your tattoo will be .
#Text=If , for example , you choose to get a tribal turtle tattoo , you may pay around $ 100 USD for the piece .
#Text=If you get the same size turtle tattoo with photorealistic detail , your piece might be closer to $ 250 - $ 300 USD .
#Text=Decide whether you want a custom or a flash piece .
#Text=A flash tattoo , such as one that you would pick from the wall or a binder in your shop , will typically cost less than a custom design .
#Text=This is because your artist wo n't have to spend any time drawing out an original piece .
#Text=Be prepared to pay more if you are getting a custom piece .
#Text=Add in the cost of the tip .
#Text=It is customary to tip your tattoo artists after they complete a session .
#Text=The customary tip for a successful tattoo is 20 % to 25 % .
#Text=At an absolute minimum , you should plan for a 10 % o 15 % tip .
#Text=Video
#Text=Tips
#Text=Remember that the cheapest tattoo is not always the best tattoo .
#Text=You are paying for quality and experience .
#Text=Shop around to get a competitive price , but be prepared to pay for a higher-end piece .
